We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). TTP is caused by the deficiency of ADAMTS13 activity, a metalloprotease that cleaves von Willebrand factor, leading to platelet adhesion and aggregation. Bleeding time will be prolonged instead of normal, as there are not enough platelets to form a clot. Splenectomy is not the treatment of choice for TTP. Plasmapheresis to remove the autoantibodies that cause the deficiency of ADAMTS13 activity is the treatment of choice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the symptoms and laboratory findings, the most likely diagnosis is thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), which is characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, fever, and neurological symptoms. TTP is caused by a deficiency of the von Willebrand factor-cleaving protease, ADAMTS13. Bleeding time may be prolonged due to thrombocytopenia. Splenectomy is not typically recommended for TTP. Plasmapheresis is the treatment of choice to remove the ADAMTS13 inhibitor and replenish it with fresh plasma containing ADAMTS13.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of low platelet count, elevated creatinine, and neurological symptoms suggests thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). The presence of schistocytes, helmet cells, and spherocytes on the peripheral smear further supports this diagnosis. TTP is caused by a deficiency in ADAMTS13 enzyme, not a sodium transporter. Bleeding time may be abnormal due to the low platelet count. Splenectomy is not the first-line treatment for TTP, and plasmapheresis is the treatment of choice to remove autoantibodies that are causing the thrombosis.
